Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Summer Rates will be charged from 2 May to 31 October.

For the convenience of families and others, a large portion of each ship’s accommodation has been reserved for Egypt, so that Berths can be definitely engaged at once, as if the voyage were commencing at Port Said. Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company’s Agents.

The through Steamers for Marseilles and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Tuesday for the present except the MONGOLIA, which is taking passengers to the Anglo-French Naval Review, and will not wait at Port-Said on 24/25 July. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before. The Fare remains as usual.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,
Messrs. THOS. COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd. CAIRO.
GEORGE ROYLE, Esq. PORT-SAID.
Messrs. HABELDEN & Co. ALEXANDRIA.
F. G. DAVIDSON, Superintendent P. & O. S. N. Company in Egypt SUEZ.

div.head: DAILY WEATHER REPORT
div.p: OBSERVATIONS BY THE SURVEY DEPARTMENT.

div.head: REMARKS.
div.p: Yesterday opened with a light breeze from the N.N.E. but towards noon the wind suddenly changed to the N.N.W. The day was rather warm, but becme beautifully cool in the evening. Barometer steady.

table.head: OTHER STATIONS.
For the 24 hours ending 3 a.m. Yesterday

div.head: The Russian Disaster
div.p: If it be true that "dark's the hour before the dawn," then Russia should be about to enjoy a sunrise of unprecendented splendour, for never, surely, has the night of her mis- fortunes been blacker, or the winter of her

discontent more severse. East and WEst, at home and in Manchuria, the future s equally shrouded in impenetrable gloom, and such speculations as it is possible to make con- cerning the course of events only seem to create that "darkness visible" which Milton imagined as the only light in Hell. Little by little we are learning what the vast Japanese host beyond the Sha-ho has succeeses in doing. Time has fought on the side of the commander nearest to his base. As everybody might, surely, have seen (but as curiously, many did not see), Russia never had a serious chance of bringing more ment into the field than Japan. And the release of Nogi's force before Port Arthur has effectually decided the question of numbers. Oyama, confident in numerical, as well as other, superiority, has acheieved a great enveloping movement and inflicted on the Russian Army the more crushing defeat of the war. The telegrams to-day form gruesome reading. Official despatches record the loss of nearly 500 guns and over 200,000 men. Ge- neral Kuropatkin, telegraphing on the 11th inst., admits that out of two regiments there were only 150 and 619 survivors respectively. The Russian dead, we are told,were everywhere, and from the 28th February to the 11th inst. 47,581 wounded were sout North. Apparently, the First Army alone is intact, the where- abouts and condition of the remainder being quite incertain. It is doubtful, says Reuter, if the remains of the shattered armies are capable of holding out, if the pursuit is pressed more. The position of the Russian Army is therefore obviously one of utter desperation. Kuropatkin has been deprived of that last blessing, an alternative. As seems in the highest degree probable, if the Japanese tactics prove suc- cessful, his retreat from Mukden will be cut off, and all that will remain will be standing still and - surrendering. In little over a day the complexion of affairs has changed. The retire- ment on Harbin has been rendered almost impossible. Probably it is quite impossible by this time. Kuroki has driven in the left flank, Nodzu is forcing back the centre, Oku and Nogi are trespassing on the right, while a strong Japanese force has obtained pos- session of the Harbin road. The Russians fight bravery - much more bravely than might have been predicted. Either they have not credited the news from the interior or their country, or they are not in so revolu- tionary a frame of mind as the reformers would have us believe. It is impossible to suppose that the fight between the Tsar and his people has had any efect on their military prowess. After all, the simple explanation may be that a Russian soldier can attend to only one thing at a time, and Kuropatkin's men have been deafened to all other considera- tions by the roar of the Japanese guns, accou- panied as it is by an insuffciency of food and by the horro of utter discouragement. The Russian soldier is the outstanding tragic item in the situation though no one bestows much thought on him.

div.head: Cape to Cairo Telegraph
div.p: Great progress has lately been made with the Cape to Cairo telgraph, which has reach- ed the little German settlement of Ujiji, on the eastern shores of Lake Tanganyika, and about 300 miles north of the extreme limit of British territory in the couthern portion of Central Africa. Arrangements are now all but completed for the commencement of a further considerable section of the line along the eastern shores of the Victoria Nyanza; and thence the line will be taken due north to Rosares, where it will be connected with the Sudanese telegraph system. It is thought that the line will be open from end to end by the end of 1906.

div.head: The Cotton Trade in Lancashire
div.p: Writing in the "Financier" of the 4th inst., Mr. W. Tattersall stated that the cotton trade in Lancashire was in a state of unexampled prosperity, excepting the fine yarn department. "Every day," he continued, "we have reports in the papers of proposals to erect weaving sheds in different parts of Lancashire. Co- operative provision societies are offering help in sevral cases. No doubt there are at the present time a fair number of sheds going up, and if the list proposed goes thorugh there will be by the end of the year a moderate increase in the number of looms. The question arises - Where are the operative weavers to come from to fill these new places I At present there is a scarcity of this kind of labour,"
